properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall continues today into Wednesday. Additional snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are possible today through Wednesday morning. Strong northerly winds gusting near 70 km/h are possible today, particularly near Lake Huron or Georgian Bay. This snowfall is a result of a strengthening low pressure system expected to move through eastern Ontario into Quebec today into Wednesday. Precipitation associated with this low pressure system is expected to move east of the area by Wednesday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-02T01:46:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-01T09:47:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3069279804.2020
Area: Bruce Peninsula - Sauble Beach - Tobermory, Hanover - Dundalk - Southern Grey County, Shelburne - Mansfield - Northern Dufferin County, Orangeville - Grand Valley - Southern Dufferin County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall accumulations of 10 to 20 cm followed by up to 25 millimetres of rain and warm temperatures may result in water pooling and localized flooding. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. A stalled front will push moisture through the Alsek Valley into the Haines Junction area. 10 to 20 cm of snow is forecast by mid morning. The snow will then change to rain and continue through to Wednesday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-02T01:25:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-01T09:26:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3882425147.2020
Area: Haines Junction
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall amounts of 15 to 30 centimetres are expected. The snow will begin during the day and end Wednesday afternoon. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of heavy rain continues. Maximum rainfall amounts: 80 to 120 mm, except possibly reach 180 mm in the extreme southwestern region of the province. Locations: most of southwestern and central New Brunswick. Time span: today through Wednesday morning. Remarks: Rain, heavy at times, will continue today and tonight before easing off Wednesday morning. Additional rainfall amounts of 50 to 100 mm are expected in most areas, however amounts today and tonight may reach 140 mm in the extreme southwest. Similar rainfall events in the past have caused road washouts and localized flooding in low-lying areas. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-02T00:35:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-01T08:36:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0586889701.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall continues today into early Wednesday. Snow, heavy at times, will continue today into the late evening. Strong northwesterly winds will create some lake enhancement off of Lake Huron. Additional snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm are possible by tonight. Strong northwesterly winds gusting near 70 km/h are possible today, particularly near Lake Huron. This snowfall is a result of a strengthening low pressure system expected to move through eastern Ontario into Quebec today into Wednesday. Precipitation associated with this low pressure system is expected to move east of the area by Wednesday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Multi-day snowfall event expected tonight into Wednesday. Total snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm are possible. Snow continues tonight with snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm possible by Tuesday morning. Additional snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are a possibility Tuesday through Wednesday, Motorists should be prepared for winter driving conditions. This snowfall is a result of a strengthening low pressure system expected to move through eastern Ontario into Quebec Tuesday into Wednesday. Precipitation associated with this low pressure system is expected to move east of the area by Wednesday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Messy week ahead with periods of snow, freezing rain, and rain expected. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Total rainfall: 10 to 40 mm. Locations: central Labrador and coastal Labrador from Nain and vicinity to Cartwright. Time span: today, Wednesday, and Thursday. Remarks: Snow will spread to coastal Labrador this morning. North of Rigolet, the precipitation is expected to remain as snow through Wednesday. From Rigolet to Cartwright and through Upper Lake Melville and Eagle River the snow will change to rain this afternoon or evening with a risk of freezing rain. Precipitation is expected to finally end later on Thursday. Snowfall and/or Rainfall Warnings might be needed for some areas in subsequent forecasts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-02T01:25:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-01T09:26:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3605805392.2020
Area: Cartwright to Black Tickle, Rigolet and vicinity, Postville - Makkovik, Hopedale and vicinity, Nain and vicinity, Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Further snowfall amounts: 10 to 20 cm. Locations: Labrador City, Wabush, Churchill Falls and vicinity, and Churchill Valley. Time span: ending today. Remarks: Snow will change to rain this afternoon over the Churchill Valley region. Further west through Churchill Falls, Labrador City, and Wabush, snow is expected to taper off in intensity and mix with ice pellets this afternoon and evening. All areas are forecast to transition to an extended and potentially significant period of freezing rain and ice pellets overnight tonight into Wednesday. A freezing rain warning has been issued as a result. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-01T22:59:45-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-01T09:25:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1970155066.2020
Area: Churchill Valley, Churchill Falls and vicinity, Labrador City and Wabush
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Warning of potential breaking sea conditions and overwash issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - Quebec Area on 2020-12-01. An intense low pressure system will generate strong southeasterly winds over the specified areas below. The combination of these winds and the current run of mid-amplitude tidal ranges may produce minor breaking sea conditions along the coast near the following localities on the dates and at the times specified (Eastern Standard Time). Forillon Park - Gaspé - Percé: 2020-12-01, from 12:00 PM to 04:00 PM. New-Carlisle - Chandler: 2020-12-01, from 12:30 PM to 04:30 PM. Anticosti: 2020-12-01, from 12:00 PM to 04:00 PM. Natashquan: 2020-12-01, from 10:00 AM to 02:00 PM. Chevery: 2020-12-01, from 09:30 AM to 01:30 PM. ### Coastal erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-01T23:29:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-01T09:42:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3131018890.2020
Area: Chandler area, New Carlisle - Port-Daniel area, Forillon National Park - Gaspé area, Percé area, Natashquan, Chevery, Anticosti
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Locations: Labrador City, Wabush, Churchill Falls and vicinity, and Churchill Valley. Time span: overnight tonight until midday Wednesday. Freezing Rain Amounts: 10 to 15 mm. Remarks: Considerable uncertainty exists with regards to this system. Current guidance suggests that temperatures will remain at or below zero overnight tonight until Wednesday afternoon, which would result in an extended and significant period of freezing rain. However, any change in the system's track could cause a premature warm-up above freezing and an early transition to rain. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-02T01:24:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-01T09:25:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1704378273.2020
Area: Churchill Valley, Churchill Falls and vicinity, Labrador City and Wabush
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long episode of heavy rain is expected. Maximum rainfall amounts: 80 to 120 mm, except possibly reach 180 mm in the extreme southwestern region of the province. Locations: most of southwestern and central New Brunswick. Time span: this evening through Wednesday morning. Remarks: A slow moving, intense low pressure system over New England will move into Quebec by Wednesday. This system will continue to push rain at times heavy into the province tonight, Tuesday, and Tuesday night before easing off Wednesday morning. At this time, rainfall amounts are expected to be heaviest in the southwestern portion of the province where general rainfall amounts of 80 to 120 mm are expected by Wednesday morning, with some areas potentially reaching near 180 mm. Similar rainfall events in the past have caused road washouts and localized flooding in low-lying areas. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-01T19:04:51-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. An intense Pacific frontal system will stall west of Haida Gwaii tonight and Tuesday. Ahead of the front, strong southeasterly winds of 80 to 100 km/h will develop over Haida Gwaii and the exposed coastal sections of the North Coast late this evening. The strong winds are expected to continue through Tuesday night. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Maximum rainfall amounts: widespread 50 to 80 mm, with some areas possibly exceeding 100 mm in areas of heaviest rain. Locations: western Nova Scotia and the north shore of the Minas Basin. Time span: today through Wednesday morning. Remarks: Heavy rain will begin to push eastward across Nova Scotia today, and continue until Wednesday morning. The highest rainfall amounts are expected in the southwest where amounts today could reach 70 mm by late afternoon. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-02T00:45:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-01T08:46:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3176136112.2020
Area: Kings County, Annapolis County, Digby County, Lunenburg County, Queens County, Shelburne County, Yarmouth County, Cumberland County - Minas Shore, Colchester County - Cobequid Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, and significant snow melt continues. Total rainfall amount: 40 to 60 mm, possibly higher in areas of heaviest rain. Location: Northwest New Brunswick. Time span: today through Wednesday morning. Remarks: Rain, heavy at times, will continue today and tonight as an intense low pressure system moves into Quebec. Addition rainfall amounts of 20 to 40 mm are expected before rain gradually ends Wednesday morning. Mild temperatures accompanying the rain will cause significant or total melting of the existing snow pack. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-02T00:36:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-01T08:37:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0913525523.2020
Area: Edmundston and Madawaska County, western half of Restigouche County, Campbellton and eastern half of Restigouche County, Grand Falls and Victoria County, Mount Carleton - Renous Highway
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A stalled front will push moisture through the Alsek Valley tonight into the Haines Junction area. 10 to 15 cm of snow is forecast by mid Tuesday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.

Description: Significant snowfall is no longer expected. ###

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Local amounts of 5 to 10 millimetres of freezing precipitation are expected beginning this evening. Freezing rain will change to rain on Wednesday. ### Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-02T01:45:10-00:00

Area: Fermont, Manic-5 area, Manic-3 area, Chutes-des-Passes - Pipmuacan Reservoir area, Labrieville area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: southeasterly up to 100 km/h in the Wreckhouse area. Time span: Late this morning until Wednesday morning. Remarks: Strong southeasterly winds consistently gusting near 90 km/h will develop this morning and will persist for the next two days. Occasional gusts up to 100 km/h are expected in the Wreckhouse area today and overnight tonight. This prolonged period of strong southeasterly winds will end Wednesday night as winds shift to the west. ### Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-02T00:46:15-00:00
